awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Effective Control to Maximize Resource Efficiency in Large Clusters;  Hardware, Runtime, and Compiler Perspectives
awd_abstract_narration:
Current computer systems use energy and other resources inefficiently. To improve efficiency, this proposal rethinks the way computer systems are controlled. This proposal uses formal methodologies based on control theory, and an analysis that cuts across software and hardware, to obtain orders of magnitude gains in resource efficiency. The proposal designs controllers in the hardware, in the runtime system, and in the compiler. The expected result is that large clusters can deliver higher performance for the same energy consumption, or consume lower energy for the same performance.

This work involves building a prototype running an experimental runtime system and a compiler. It develops a set of technologies that will improve the resource efficiency of general-purpose computers by one or more orders of magnitude. The work will enable current technology computers to continue delivering increased capabilities, providing economic benefits to our society. The research has four thrusts: adapting control theory to computer architecture, developing hardware controllers, extending runtime systems to actuate on the hardware, and compiler-driven control. This research will be performed in collaboration with AMD Corporation Research. 

This effort enhances multidisciplinary research and education on cluster and datacenter technologies at the University of Illinois. The material in this work will enhance the courses on computer architecture, runtime systems, compilation, and parallel programming that the investigators are teaching. This work will place undergraduates and under-represented students in research groups. The research will also have a major impact on industry, since it addresses a real, very timely technical problem: that of making our cluster and datacenter infrastructure more energy efficient.

This project will produce various deliverables that will be placed in a website for the community to access. The project repository will include data, code, results, a hardware emulator, a runtime system, and a compiler. These materials will be made available for at least two years beyond the project's lifetime. They will be accessible from http://iacoma.cs.uiuc.edu.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this proposal, the Principal Investigators (PIs) have focused on improving the energy efficiency and the performance of computer systems. The method used is the development of intelligent control systems for computers. The PIs used formal methodologies based on control theory and machine learning, and embodied them in hardware, compiler, and runtime system designs. The work enabled CMOS-based computers to continue delivering increased capabilities, providing economic benefits to our society.

The specific technical outcome of this work has been the design of multiple mechanisms that deliver major gains in resource efficiency in processors, heterogeneous compute units, and clusters of computers. One set of contributions relates to using control theory to support hardware and software controllers in a variety of settings. The work culminated in the design of a hardware controller for heterogeneous clusters of processors and GPUs. The controller is a hierarchy of distributed controllers associated with compute units, operating in a coordinated manner with low latency and scalably. The controller ideas and design was jointly patented with AMD.

Another set of contributions is the design of a controller that secures computers. The idea is to use control theory principles to obfuscate the power emanations from a computer running a program. Thanks to the obfuscation, a malicious computer connected to the same power lines as the victim computer in the same building cannot identify what are the programs running on the victim computer.

Other contributions include machine learning controllers that help identify the best algorithms to use to solve sparse matrix computations based on the structure of the sparse matrix being processed, and intelligent runtime systems that leverage per-core Dynamic Voltage and Frequency Scaling (DVFS) to dynamically change the frequency and voltage of processors for each loop of a high-performance computing program.

This effort enhanced multidisciplinary research and education on datacenter technologies at the University of Illinois. The advances in this work were incorporated in courses on computer architecture, runtime systems, compilation, and parallel programming that the investigators are teaching. The work funded 9 graduate students, of which three already completed their PhD and joined Yale University, Intel, and Nvidia. The research was conducted in close collaboration with researchers at AMD, Intel, Nvidia, and IBM. It is hoped that the proposed designs and implementations will have an impact on these companies' products.
